That’s why I will vote YES on this bipartisan innovation and competition bill.

This will improve our supply chains.
This will help lower costs.
This will help protect our country.

The U.S. must lead the world in innovation.

This innovation and competition bill ensures that we are building a stronger economy and lowering prices for our families and businesses. (8/9)

By increasing manufacturing, workforce training, and innovative research here in the U.S., we help equip our businesses with the resources to get ahead and stay ahead.

Across our state, I’ve heard from business leaders about the importance of passing this legislation. (7/9)
This package will also help businesses in New Hampshire and across the country compete in our global marketplace and bring jobs back to the U.S. (6/9)
By protecting and growing our supply chains at home, we reduce reliance on countries like China and bolster our national security. (5/9)

From cell phones and cars to microwaves and military equipment, semiconductors are everywhere.

Without a secure supply of them, we’re vulnerable to rising costs or compromised military equipment. (4/9)

We’ve seen the risk that poses to our economic security and our national security – and it’s time we change that.

This bill invests in American semiconductor manufacturing and research and development. (3/9)

China is out-manufacturing the U.S. & it’s past time we invest in American workers & manufacturing.

For far too long, American innovators have had to rely on other countries for technology and critical supplies. (2/9)

TODAY, the Senate will vote to pass a bill that will ensure that the U.S. can better compete - and stay ahead - in our global economy.

I wanted to take a moment to share how important this bill is to our daily lives. ⬇️

We found that Bushmaster, Ruger, Sig Sauer, Daniel Defense, and Smith & Wesson do not track the death and injuries caused by their products. 
 
None of these companies produced any documents requested by the Committee on this matter or about the risks posed by their marketing.

The gun industry has used white supremacist imagery in its ads. This example from Daniel Defense features shows a shooter with a tattoo of a symbol known as the Valknot. 
 
This symbol is associated w/ white supremacists and is marked a hate symbol by the Anti-Defamation League. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FYraDXXWIAEoZzP.png

Video game imagery is also used to sell guns to young people. 
 
The Smith & Wesson ad below the company uses one person shooter camera shots. We also found that gun manufacturers enter into licensing agreements to have their weapons featured in first-person shooter video games. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FYrZ3QFXEAUASTz.png

Gun manufactures prey on the concept of masculinity to sell their weapons. One commentator found that the intended effect of these ads appeared to be to “humiliate men into arming themselves with combat weapons.”

✅ Continuing Science and Space Exploration. 

With the NASA reauthorization, we’re committing to the importance of space and science exploration by supporting @NASA research and development for programs like Artemis, which will bring Americans to the Moon and to Mars.

✅ Increasing State EPSCoR Funding for STEM Research 

CHIPS+ will improve geographic diversity by dedicating up to 20% of NSF funds to states & jurisdictions participating in EPSCoR, which builds research and STEM capacity in areas receiving <0.75% of the NSF budget.

✅ Expanding the Educational Capacity for Research

CHIPS+ will create a capacity-building program for universities to increase and improve research, engage small businesses, and close STEM workforce gaps by supporting entrepreneurial training & hands-on experiences for students

✅ Creating a Diverse STEM Workforce.

The CHIPS+ legislation will provide scholarships and fellowships to expand diversity in STEM.

✅ Authorizing the NSF Technology Directorate

The @NSF is the gold standard for basic research around the world. We’re authorizing the first-of-its-kind NSF Technology Directorate that’s dedicated to accelerating the development and translation of new technologies within the US

✅ Building Regional Tech Hubs

Harnessing the power of geographic diversity across the U.S., this bill will invest $10B to build multiple regional tech hubs that focus on developing technologies, entrepreneurship, boosting supply chains and expanding our innovation capabilities http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FYsV3Q7agAA7mJh.jpg

✅ Turning Ideas from Lab-to-Market at Faster Speeds. 

American colleges & universities play a key role in research. CHIPS+ will help turn ideas and research into real products faster to jumpstart American innovation. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FYsVyw5aIAA3etK.jpg

✅Investing in US Manufacturing & Jobs

We’re creating resilient supply chains and good-paying jobs here at home. The @NIST Manufacturing Extension Partnership expansion adds workforce development opportunities as small/medium-sized manufacturers demand more skilled STEM workers

✅Building Chips in America

The US is no longer a global leader in chip production, 37% in 90s to 12% now. The shortage & dependency on imported chips is a grave economic & national security issue

Investing in US chips will create jobs, secure supply chains & support innovation http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FYsVnpDXoAIF5eZ.jpg

We honored Lopez among 43,808 names today. Today on Armistice Day when the Korean War ended. As I walked along the wall it was stunning to see all the names in one place. I realized nearly all were privates or young in their service. Men in their teens and early 20s. 5/7 http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FYs-VPqWAAIlIUy.jpg

I walked the memorial and saw the name Baldomero Lopez carved in stone. He was photographed climbing this sea wall before being shot by NorthKorean army as he held a grenade, which fell by fellow marines. With last ounce of life he smothered the grenade and absorbed the blast.4/7 http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FYs-UnYX0AUCXpn.jpg http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FYs-UneWIAATqs1.jpg

These servicemembers were the best of America. And today I got to sit among these heroes to honor those that gave their lives for our freedom. Those that died so my forefathers and mothers could survive the brutal North Korean regime that sought to end their way of life. 3/7 http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FYs-UAIXkAQeo_D.jpg

These Americans around me saved the lives of my grandparents and gave my parents a future. My parents told me the first Americans they ever met were servicemembers. My parents loved America from a young age because of them and sparked their dream of one day going to America.2/7 http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FYs-TQ8WQAIIdpM.jpg

Today I had a profound moment at the opening of Korean War Wall of Remembrance. The MC asked those who served in the war to stand. I saw a man a few seats away rise and a few more around. Here I was, a KoreanAmerican realizing I would not be here today were it not for them.THREAD http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FYs-SJ-WYAQ_v-Y.jpg

https://www.speaker.gov/newsroom/72722-2

Thanks to @HouseDemocrats’ commitment to helping every American thrive in the 21st Century Economy, this legislation will power innovation — investing in next-generation technology, broadening our STEM workforce & establishing job-creating hubs in communities nationwide.
Crucially, these federal investments come with strong guardrails, ensuring they go straight into our economy — not into corporate pockets.
Once enacted, the CHIPS and Science Act will bolster our nation’s production of semiconductor chips — reinvigorating American manufacturing and creating nearly 100,000 good-paying, union jobs.

This bold, bipartisan legislation contains key House proposals to lower costs, create good-paying jobs, reduce our dependence on foreign manufacturers and turbocharge American innovation. It is a major victory for American families and the American economy.

With the Senate’s passage of the CHIPS and Science Act, Congress has taken a key step toward enacting transformative investments to strengthen families’ financial future, boost America’s research advantage and safeguard our economic and national security for generations to come.
